'''''Ileodictyon cibarium''''' is a [[saprobic]] species of fungus in the [[family (biology)|family]] [[Phallaceae]]. It is found in Australia,<ref>{{cite web |title=''Ileodictyon cibarium''|work= Atlas of Living Australia|url=http://bie.ala.org.au/species/a3a54af5-fc82-419e-b134-c1af00afbdf7|accessdate=2017-06-16}}</ref> New Zealand and South Africa, where it commonly known as the '''basket fungus''' or the '''white basket fungus''', alluding to the [[basidiocarp|fruit bodies]] that are shaped somewhat like a round or oval ball with interlaced or latticed branches. While the immature volvae are edible, the mature fruit body is foul-smelling and covered with a [[gleba|slime layer]] containing [[spore]]s on the inner surfaces.

==Description==
[[File:NZ basket fungus (Ileodictyon cibarium).JPG|thumb|left|Basket fungus mature fruit body, showing covering of green/brown slime containing spores]]
Prior to the opening of the [[volva (mycology)|volva]], the fruit body is egg-shaped and white to grayish in color. After opening, it is a whitish ball of meshes.

===Habitat===
[[File:Cross section of the unopened fruiting body of the New Zealand basket fungus (Ileodictyon cibarium), next to a ballpoint pen..JPG|thumb|left|Cross section of the unopened fruiting body of the New Zealand basket fungus (Ileodictyon cibarium), next to a ballpoint pen]]
This fungus grows alone or clustered together near woody debris, in lawns, gardens, and cultivated soil.

==Edibility==
The immature volvae are [[edible mushroom|edible]] however unappealing.
